citations.narrative:
The facility did not notify the Animal Welfare Operations office of an additional address prior to moving animals to a new
address. All licensees must notify the Animal Welfare Operations office of any change or additional addresses where
animals are housed no fewer than 90 before use of the new facility. All addresses where animals are housed must be
updated to ensure animal care inspectors are aware of new facilities to carry out there duties and ensure all animals and
facilities are inspected for compliance with the Animal Welfare Act. The licensees must notify the Animal Welfare
Operations office of any addition addresses to inspect no fewer than 90 days prior to use.
Corrected at time of inspection

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
-Bella a seven-year-old female pig was acquired by the facility in December 2022. Bella was noted to have long toes on
her front feet. Bella appears at times to be reluctant to place weight on her rear feet while standing. When walking Bella
has an awkward gate that appears as if she is unsure of herself when placing her rear feet on the ground. This gate could
be indicative of some sort of neurological condition or deficit. Undiagnosed and treated medical conditions can contribute
to unnecessary discomfort and stress for this pig. Bella needs to be evaluated by the attending veterinarian for this
condition and her feet need to be trimmed.
-The facility has expired Bovine Rhinotracheitis, Parainfluenza, Respiratory Syncytial Virus vaccines. There are a mix of
this vaccine in a single box. Some vials have an expiration of 11AUG20, and some have an expiration date of 22NOV22.
The facility also has an expired container of Medicated Wound Care. The expiration date on the wound care is May/2017.
The use of expired drugs is not an appropriate method to prevent or treat injury or illness. The efficacy of these products
beyond their expiration date is uncertain. Use of these drugs could lead to failure to prevent or treat illness causing animal
harm and suffering.

There is no contingency plan for emergencies or disasters that would affect the animals held at the facility. All exhibitors
must develop, document and follow a plan to provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing and
care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster. This plan must cover all anticipated emergencies that
would be detrimental to the good health and well-being of the animals in the facilities possession. A contingency plan for
emergencies and/or disasters must be developed and documented for the protection of the animals at the facility.
To be corrected by March 8, 2023

-A Holstein cow named Daisy has been moved to an enclosure inside the main barn. This enclosure used to house
sheep, and has a low ceiling. Daisy's head nearly touches the ceiling and there are at least two nails, two screws and a
hook hanging from the ceiling.
-There is a single, male production pig in an enclosure in the main barn. The fencing is 4" by 4" squares, and there is a
horizontal wire that is broken that is creating sharp points. The pig was observed sticking its head through the broken
fence with the sharp points.
Housing facilities for animals shall be shall be maintained in good repair without sharp points that could injure the animals
contained in the enclosure. The licensee must ensure that there are no sharp points in primary enclosures that can cause
injury to the animals contained in the enclosure.

There are two male sheep in an enclosure in the barn that contains male sheep and goats. There is standing water with
frozen ice on top and mud and muck in the outside portion of the enclosure. The water receptacle for the two sheep is in
the outside portion of the enclosure and the sheep have to walk through the standing water, mud and muck to get to their
water receptacle. A method to rapidly eliminate standing water must be provided to protect the animals from being wetted
in the cold water, mud, and muck to access their water receptacle.

One male sheep housed by itself, one male goat housed by itself, 3 jersey cows housed together, 2 jersey cows housed
with a Holstein and Angus cross, 3 female sheep housed together and 3 goats housed together have enclosures with 15"
to 18" of manure pack. Excreta shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination
of the animals contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors. Enclosures must be cleaned as
often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animal enclosed, reduce disease hazards, reduce pest infestation, and
reduce odors.
This inspection was conducted with the animal care manager and exit interview were conducted with the Executive
Director.
Additional Inspectors:
KURT HAMMEL, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICEREnd Section

narrative:
2.1(b)(1) 
   
Requirements and application 
The facility did not notify the Animal Welfare Operations office of an additional address  prior to moving animals to a new 
address.  All licensees must notify the Animal Welfare Operations office of any change or additional addresses where 
animals are housed no fewer than 90 before use of the new facility.  All addresses where animals are housed must be 
updated to ensure animal care inspectors are aware of new facilities to carry out there duties and ensure all animals and 
facilities are inspected for compliance with the Animal Welfare Act.  The licensees must notify the Animal Welfare 
Operations office of any addition addresses to inspect no fewer than 90 days prior to use. 
Corrected at time of inspection 
2.40(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
-Bella a seven-year-old female pig was acquired by the facility in December 2022.  Bella was noted to have long toes on 
her front feet.  Bella appears at times to be reluctant to place weight on her rear feet while standing.  When walking Bella 
has an awkward gate that appears as if she is unsure of herself when placing her rear feet on the ground.  This gate could 
be indicative of some sort of neurological condition or deficit. Undiagnosed and treated medical conditions can contribute 
to unnecessary discomfort and stress for this pig.  Bella needs to be evaluated by the attending veterinarian for this 
condition and her feet need to be trimmed.

-The facility has expired Bovine Rhinotracheitis, Parainfluenza, Respiratory Syncytial Virus vaccines.  There are a mix of 
this vaccine in a single box.  Some vials have an expiration of 11AUG20, and some have an expiration date of 22NOV22.  
The facility also has an expired container of Medicated Wound Care.  The expiration date on the wound care is May/2017.  
The use of expired drugs is not an appropriate method to prevent or treat injury or illness. The efficacy of these products 
beyond their expiration date is uncertain. Use of these drugs could lead to failure to prevent or treat illness causing animal 
harm and suffering. 
2.134(a) 
   
Contingency planning. 
There is no contingency plan for emergencies or disasters that would affect the animals held at the facility.  All exhibitors 
must develop, document and follow a plan to provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing and 
care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster.  This plan must cover all anticipated emergencies that 
would be detrimental to the good health and well-being of the animals in the facilities possession.  A contingency plan for 
emergencies and/or disasters must be developed and documented for the protection of the animals at the facility. 
To be corrected by March 8, 2023 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
-A Holstein cow named Daisy has been moved to an enclosure inside the main barn.  This enclosure used to house 
sheep, and has a low ceiling. Daisy's head nearly touches the ceiling and there are at least two nails, two screws and a 
hook hanging from the ceiling. 
-There is a single, male production pig in an enclosure in the main barn.  The fencing is 4" by 4" squares, and there is a 
horizontal wire that is broken that is creating sharp points.  The pig was observed sticking its head through the broken 
fence with the sharp points.

Housing facilities for animals shall be shall be maintained in good repair without sharp points that could injure the animals 
contained in the enclosure.  The licensee must ensure that there are no sharp points in primary enclosures that can cause 
injury to the animals contained in the enclosure. 
3.127(c)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
There are two male sheep in an enclosure in the barn that contains male sheep and goats.  There is standing water with 
frozen ice on top and mud and muck in the outside portion of the enclosure.  The water receptacle for the two sheep is in 
the outside portion of the enclosure and the sheep have to walk through the standing water, mud and muck to get to their 
water receptacle.  A method to rapidly eliminate standing water must be provided to protect the animals from being wetted 
in the cold water, mud, and muck to access their water receptacle. 
3.131(a)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
One male sheep housed by itself, one male goat housed by itself, 3 jersey cows housed together, 2 jersey cows housed 
with a Holstein and Angus cross, 3 female sheep housed together and 3 goats housed together have enclosures with 15" 
to 18" of manure pack. Excreta shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination 
of the animals contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors.  Enclosures must be cleaned as 
often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animal enclosed, reduce disease hazards, reduce pest infestation, and 
reduce odors. 
 
This inspection was conducted with the animal care manager and exit interview were conducted with the Executive 
Director.

Additional Inspectors: 
KURT HAMMEL, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICEREnd Section

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
